Award.AwardTitle: Important Correlations Between Local Structure and Thermoelectric Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
The thermoelectric effect is the conversion of a voltage difference to a temperature difference and vice versa. A material that exhibits a large thermoelectric effect is called a thermoelectric material. A measure of how big an effect a material exhibits is called the material's 'figure of merit' and is designated ZT. Developing new thermoelectric materials with a high value of ZT is an important national goal for both energy and cooling applications and requires an understanding of the behavior of new materials at both atomic and macroscopic scales. This individual investigator award supports a project that will carry out local structure investigations for a series of thermoelectric materials to better understand the local (atomic-level) physics that controls important parameters that determine ZT, such as a very low thermal conductivity and a high power factor. These measurements will determine local distortions, distributions of atoms in the crystals, and changes in the electronic structure; such results provide constraints for theoretical models and important feedback to the project's collaborators who are developing new materials. This project will provide educational and research opportunities for both undergraduate (Senior theses) and graduate students (PhD theses); the students will also gain important experience working as a team at national synchrotron facilities.


****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Developing new thermoelectric materials with a high figure of merit, ZT, is an important national goal and will require detailed characterizations of new materials at both the local and macroscopic levels. This individual investigator project will use X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) to investigate the local structure of a series of new materials to elucidate the local (atomic-level) physics, which determines the unusual low thermal conductivity and the recently observed enhancement of the power factor when a few specific dilute impurities are added to some systems. The low thermal conductivity is attributed to various types of local disorder within each material which is easily determined using XAS. Changes in the electronic structure about defect atoms will be probed via changes in the shape of the absorption edges. These results will provide important constraints for theoretical models and crucial feedback to the project's collaborators who are developing new materials. This project will provide educational and research opportunities for both undergraduate (Senior theses) and graduate students (PhD theses); these students will also gain significant experience working as a team at national synchrotron facilities.

The properties of any material are determined by the local arrangement of atoms at the atomic scale. The building blocks are the unit cells; tiny units that when stacked together form a macroscopic crystal - somewhat like tiles cover a floor. There can be small differences between unit cells, and these play an important role in macroscopic properties. One of the best ways to probe the local atomic structure, and the only way for dilute impurities, is to use the extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) technique. It can measure the average bond length to about 0.01 A, and from temperature dependent studies, determine the effective spring constants between atoms as well as estimates of static local disorder.

For thermoelectric materials many systems must be doped to have a reasonable electrical conductivity, but the crucial property for an excellent thermoelectric figure of merit,  is to have an unusually low thermal conductivity - similar to that of a glass. The materials investigated under this grant have very low thermal conductivity, usually attributed to low energy vibration modes of the atoms in the unit cell.  However exactly how a low thermal conductivity is achieved - and how this might be optimized, is still under debate. Most of the systems considered here have low energy vibrations, attributed for some materials such as clathrates and skutterudites, to cage-like structures in the crystalline structure. Atoms can be placed inside these "cages"  and vibrate with low energies much like stones in a rattle; hence such atoms are called ``rattlers".

For clathrates, there are two different cages in the lattice, formed of atoms such as silicon (Si), germanium (Ge), or tin (Sn).  However when some these atoms are substituted by gallium (Ga), the cages can be filled with atoms such as barium (Ba) or strontium (Sr) forming compounds such as Ba8Ga16X30; X = Si, Ge, Sn. More importantly, the cages can then become distorted.  Although the thermal conductivity is lowest for X=Sn, this compound does not have the best figure of merit. EXAFS studies show that there are very large distortions in this material because of the large size difference between Ga and Sn and this disorder reduces both the electrical conductivity and the thermal conductivity.  In contrast for the X=Ge compound, Ga and Ge are comparable in size and there is very little disorder in the cage structure. Consequently, the electrical conductivity is much higher than for Sn and the low thermal conductivity is attributed primarily to the rattling motion of Ba in the cages, and not disorder.
